item.title: Comment on Monday assorted links by Jimmy
item.description:
Reply to Color me surprised:

I’m surprised!

Years ago I read Michael Pettis’s book on TC’s recommendation due to this post:

“ Last night I read the new and excellent Michael Pettis book Avoiding the Fall: China’s Economic Restructuring. It is the single best treatment I know for understanding the dilemmas of the current Chinese economy and the need for restructuring. My favorite bits are those comparing the current Chinese economy to the Brazilian growth of the 1960s and 70s, also investment-driven, and lasting longer than most people thought possible, and culminating in the crack-up of the 1980s, which turned out to be a lost decade for Brazil.”

I can see how Trade Wars Are Class Wars might disagee with TCs free trade commitments, but I’d love to know why he thinks Pettis simply does not understand IE all of a sudden.

I have no dog in this fight, but it is worth noting that the number of public people who said smart things ten+ years ago that are saying not smart things now is surprisingly large.

Is it a sort-of over-emphasis on "Accounting" that leads to a values-riches fallacy? Is it literally that thing in its fullness, or a more general undervaluing of short-to-medium-term elasticities? Something else...?
